Name: Is there a distinct category of dual for verbal agreement with a dual subject?
Comment: There was agreement in the Nortern dialects of Skolt Saami quite recently but not anymore.

Name: Is non-agreement in number between the nominal subject and verbal predicate possible?
Can finite verbs agree in number with a nominal object?
Can an adnominal property word agree with the noun in case?
Is there non-agreement between an adnominal property word and the head noun?
Comment: Adjectives don't (usually) agree with the noun case at all.

Name: Can adpositions be used to mark core verbal arguments?
Can non-finite clauses use a special means for core argument (S/A) marking?
Can non-finite clauses use a special means for core argument (P) marking?
Do characteristics of the object referent (topicality, animacy, definiteness) influence object marking?
Does object marking correlate with aspectuality?
Does object marking depend on the verb conjugation form?
Is there differential subject marking?
Can S and A be conflated morphologically across clause boundaries, i.e., act as a syntactic pivot?
Can S and P be conflated morphologically across clause boundaries, i.e., act as a syntactic pivot?
Is there grammatical marking of habituality?
Is there grammatical marking of frequentativity?
Is there grammatical marking of progressivity?
Comment: Progressive aspect is marked with the auxiliary verb + the progressive participle of the main verb.

Name: Is it common to use a verb in the present tense for future time reference?
Is there grammatical marking of the immediate future?
Is there grammatical marking of pluperfect?
Can aspect be expressed overtly in the negative marker?
Can tense be expressed overtly in the negative marker?
Is there grammatical marking of mirativity?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of a desire or wish?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to irrealis?
Comment: Morphological marking for conditional is č.

Name: Are verbs marked in a non-indicative mood in counterfactual conditional clauses?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of deontic necessity?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of epistemic possibility?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of deontic possibility?
Is there morphological marking on the verb used to direct commands/wishes, etc. to the 3Sg?
Is there morphological marking on the verb used to direct commands/wishes, etc. to the 1Sg?
Is it common to use the imperative/jussive in complement clauses introduced by predicates expressing wish/desire/will?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of apprehension?
Is there a reflexive conjugation?
Can non-singular 2nd and 3rd person have the same person/number marking or morphosyntactic treatment?
Can 3rd person plural verb forms be used for impersonal reference?
Are 2nd singular verb forms commonly used with a generic meaning?
Can an infinitival verb form function as a predicate in an imperative clause?
Can verbs in purposive subordinate clauses be in the bare infinitive form?
Are there sentences without overt verbal arguments?
Is a copula commonly used for predicate nominals in the 3rd person singular forms of the present tense?
Is a copula commonly used for predicate nominals in the past tense?
Is it common to omit a copula in locative constructions?
Is the same coordinating conjunction commonly used for NPs, VPs, and clauses?
Does existential negation have a special negator?
Can standard negation be asymmetric in the present tense?
Can non-finite dependent clauses use the standard negation construction?
Is there a special negator that combines with non-finite forms?
Are there special negative non-finite forms?
Is there an impersonal passive construction?
Are there non-finite forms specializing in the relativization of particular core participants, e.g., subjects (S/A), direct objects (P), absolutive participants (S/P)?
Are there non-finite forms that can relativize at least all core participants (S/A/P) and possibly also some non-core participants?
Are there non-finite forms that can relativize at least some non-core participants but cannot relativize all or some of the core participants?
Is there a specialized negative participial form, which cannot be analyzed as a specific participial marker + negation marker?
Comment: In some varieties it is possible to say e.g., puuđkani jieʹllem (end.ABE.PTCP life.SG.NOM) 'a life without an end'.

Name: Is there a future participle?
Are there participles that can encode their subject with possessive suffixes?
Are there participles that must agree with the nouns they modify in case and number?
Are there non-finite forms that can be used both as participles and action nominalizations?
Are there non-finite forms that can be used both as participles and agentive nominalizations?
Are there non-finite forms that can be used both as participles and converbs?
Is OV the neutral order in affirmative imperative clauses?
Is it pragmatically neutral to place an object between the negative marker and the main verb in imperative constructions?
Comment: Possible, but such sentences are not neutral.

Name: Are there preverbs?
Is there diminutive (hypocoristic) marking on verbs?
Can modifiers of action nominalizations in agent and patient roles both be encoded like possessors?
Can the modifier of action nominalizations in the patient role be encoded like the direct object?
Do core adjectives agree with the subject noun in number in the predicative position?
Is there morphological superlative marking on the property word?
Can adpositions have person/number marking?
Are there adpositions that show a three-partite system?
Is there case compounding?
Are there morphological cases only used with pronouns?
Does the numeral modification of a noun have an effect on its case selection?
Comment: Nouns modified by numerals bigger than six are in the partitive, smaller than seven are in the genitive.

Name: Is the singular form of the noun also used with numerals greater than 1?
Is there a dedicated case that expresses indirect object/recipient/goal (different from a local case)?
Is there a dedicated case that expresses a terminative meaning?
Is there a dedicated case that expresses the absence of a referent (abessive)?
Is there a dedicated case that expresses motion along or by a referent (prolative)?
Is there a locative case that expresses goal?
Is there a locative case that expresses location?
Is there a locative case that expresses source?
Is there case syncretism for goal and location marking?
Is there case syncretism for location and source marking?
Are there two sets of local cases?
Are there three or more sets of local cases?
Is there a dedicated case that expresses the means by which something is carried out (instrumental) and/or accompaniement (comitative)?
Is there a case that expresses instrument (instrumental), which is different from a case that expresses accompaniment (comitative)?
Is there a dedicated case that expresses the result of a change (translative) and/or a state of being (essive)?
Is there a case that expresses the result of a change (translative), which is different from a case that expresses a state of being (essive)?
Is there morphological marking dedicated to the expression of equativity?
Is there an inflectional nominal marker for expressing benefactive or destinative semantics independent from the dative?
Is there (in addition to the basic declension) a declension different from a possessive declension?
Is it possible to use the singular with paired body parts/clothing/accessories that accompany them?
Can the marking of the possessor in the attributive construction vary?
Can the possessor in the attributive construction be encoded with the nominative?
Is non-singular possession marked in the possessive declension?
Can a 2Sg possessive suffix be used to mark definiteness?
Can a 3Sg possessive suffix be used to mark definiteness?
Is there a human vs. non-human distinction in independent interrogative pronouns?
When used as a relative pronoun, is it common to use 'who' for animates other than humans?
When used as a relative pronoun, is it common to use 'who' for inanimates?
Can a demonstrative stem be used in the function of a pronoun with a 3Sg human referent?
Are there possessive suffixes the position of which can vary in relation to case/number suffixes?
Comment: In the comitative and abessive cases the case suffix follows the possessive suffix, whereas in  other cases it precedes the possessive suffix. However, the case and possessive suffix cannot always be separated.

Name: Is the order of number and case suffixes the same across the paradigm?
Are there different words for mother’s brother and father’s brother?
Are there different words for younger and older relatives for relations other than siblings?
Is there an animacy distinction for both concepts:'new/young' and 'old'?
Is there a distinction for both 'warm' and 'cold' depending on whether reference is to weather or the temperature of objects?
Is there contrastive length for consonants?
Is there contrastive length for vowels?
Is there a contrast between short and long unstressed vowels?
Is there a contrast in the length of geminate consonants?
Are there more than two phonological quantities?
Are there extralong syllables?
Is the main foot structure trochaic?
Is there lexically distinctive word stress?
Is there morphologically conditioned stress?
Comment: ue' is stressed

Name: Is there fixed primary stress?
Is there stress in heavy syllables?
Is there non-initial primary stress?
Is there palatal vowel harmony?
Comment: There is some kind of vowel harmony but this does not depend on the frontness/backness of vowels.

Name: Is there velar vowel harmony?
Comment: There is no ɤ or ɯ in Skolt Saami.

Name: Is there labial vowel harmony?
Are there closing diphthongs?
Comment: All diphtongs are lowering.

Name: Are there opening diphthongs?
Comment: All diphtongs are lowering:iɘ ‹iõ› ‹iõʹ›, uɘ ‹uõ› ‹uõʹ›, eæ ‹eä› ‹eäʹ›, uæ ‹uä› ‹uäʹ›, eᴈ ‹eâ› ‹eäʹ›, uᴈ ‹uâ› ‹uẹʹ›, ie ‹ieʹ›, ue ‹ueʹ›, (iε ‹iẹʹ›), (uε ‹uẹʹ›), iᴈ ‹iâ›, uɔ ‹uå›

Name: Is there a qualitative contrast between subsets of short and long vowels?
Are there full vs. reduced vowels as contrastive subsets?
Is there a high front rounded vowel /y/?
Comment: [y] exists only in new loanwords, e.g. fysikk 'physics'.

Name: Is there a mid-high front rounded vowel /ø/?
Is there a high back unrounded vowel /ɯ ɨ/?
Is there a mid-high back unrounded vowel /ɤ ɘ/?
Is there a low back rounded vowel /ɒ/?
Comment: The phoneme marked <å> in standard ortography can be realised as [ɒ] in some varieties, but more commonly as [ɔ] or [oa].

Name: Is there a contrast between mid front vowels (/e/ or /ɛ/) and low front vowels (/æ/ or /a/)?
Are there word-initial consonant clusters?
Comment: Also ståkkan 'glass', prääʹzniǩ 'celebration' etc.

Name: Are there word-internal consonant clusters in the syllable onset?
Are there consonant clusters in the syllable coda?
Are there word-internal intervocalic clusters of three or more consonants?
Are there word-final clusters of three or more consonants?
Comment: In word forms such as verstt [verstːᵃ] the consonant cluster is not phonologically word-final, because it is followed by a reduced (overshort) vowel.

Name: Are there palatalized alveolar consonants?
Comment: Skolt Saami has suprasegmental palatalization, so the difference between mââʹnn [mᴈːnʲːᵉ] 'egg' and mâânn [mᴈːnːᵃ] go.PRS.3SG is strictly speaking not only that of [n] vs. [nʲ].

Name: Are there palatalized labial and velar consonants?
Comment: Suprasegmental palatalization apparently does not affect labials, and velars become wholly palatal by its effect (e.g. k > ǩ (c)-.

Name: Is there a palatal stop?
Is there a palatal nasal /ɲ/?
Is there a palatal lateral /ʎ/?
Is there a velar nasal /ŋ/?
Is there an alveolar affricate /t͡s/?
Is there a non-alveolar affricate (e.g., /t͡ʃ/, /t͡ɕ/)?
Is there a phonological contrast between an unvoiced alveolar sibilant /s/ and an unvoiced postalveolar sibilant /ʃ/?
Are there voiced plosives (e.g., /b g d/)?
Comment: Also aabbâs 'ABC-book', kruuggâst circle.SG.LOC, bliin 'pancake', domm 'house', boʹhtter 'hero'.

Name: Is there a glottal stop /ʔ/?
Is there a phonological contrast between plain and labial velar consonants (e.g., /k/ vs. /kʷ/)?
Is there a constraint on the word-initial alveolar trill /r/?
Is there a laryngeal fricative /h/?
Comment: However, word-initial h may also be pronounced [x].

Name: Is there a voiced velar fricative /ɣ/?
Is there a voiceless velar fricative /x/?
Comment: This sound reminds the respective sound in Russian and it differs from the Finnish [h].

Name: Is there a voiced dental fricative /ð/?
Is there a labio-velar approximant /w/?
Comment: The "l-vocalization" in non-palatal environments is a relatively recent phenomenon and does not occur in all dialects, but it is favored in modern standard language.

Name: Is there a voiceless labiodental fricative /f/?
Is there radical qualitative consonant gradation?
Is there quantitative consonant gradation?
